In June of 1976, George F. Abbitt, Jr. announced bis retirement as Judge in the .10th Judicial Circuit after twelve years on the circuit court bench i The 10th circuit includes South Boston, Appomattox, Charlotte, Halifax, Prince Ed ward, Cumberland, Bucking ham, Lunenburg and Mecklen burg Counties. In accepting the résiliation of Abbitt, who was 70 August 6, 1976, Govern- Mills E. Godwin  applauded Abbitts distingu ished contributions and exempl ary service in his high office. Before being appointed to fill the unexpired term of Judge Joel W. Flood in 1964, Judge Abbitt was commonwealths attorney in Appomattox Coun ty from 1948. A native of Newport News and a graduate of Appomattox j High School and the University of Richmond, Judge Abbitt served as substitute county court judge from 1939 to 1943 nd chairman of the county supervisors from 1943 to 1948. Abbitt is married to the former Josephine Cundiff of

Lewis McDeaav man, charged with murder in the Sept. 21 pistol slaying of Mor ton Lewis Ferguson, is schedul ed to begin at 10 a.m. today, Thursday, before Circuit Court Judge Joel W Flood. document.text: Judge Joel W. Flood has appoint ed A. L. Pitts to be commonwealths attorney for Buckingham County, to fill out the unexpired term- of Mr. Hubbard, who resigned the of fice this week.

George F. Abbitt, Jr., 57, of Appomattox, was appointed Judge of the Fifth Judicial Circuit of Virginia, late Friday aft ernoon by Governor Albertis S. Harrison. Abbitt, who is a brother of Fourth District Congressman Watkins M. Abbitt, has been commonwealths attorney of Ap pomattox since he succeeded his brother in that position in 1948. He was appointed at th at time by the late Judge Joel W. Flood, whom he now follows as the circuit judge. ------------------------------------------- 1 The vacancy in the circuit judgeship occurred April 27, when Judge Flood died after an illness of several months. Thè. interim appointment was made by the governor and is effective until 30 days after the next General Assembly session, when as customary, formal election of the new judge will take placé. Judge Floods term was to have expired Feb. 1, 1970. Abbitt received the judicial nod over County Judge William P. Hay, Jr., of Prince Edward County. Delegations in behalf of both candidates appeared before Governor Harrison, prior to his decision. Abbitt Is a graduate of Appo mattox High School and holds a law degree from the University of Richmond. He entered private practice In 1931 in his home town and has been there since. He served as chairman of the Appomattox board of supervisors from 1942 to 1948. He had been appointed to the board by the late Judge Flood. Abbitt is a

document.text: Col , Joel W. Flood, of Appo mattox, has received wide endorse ment for the judicial vacancy caus ed by the death of Judge Robert. F, Hutcheson. A causcus of the Democrats in the General Assembly is scheduled to be held next Tuesday to nominate a candidate to succeed udge Hutcheson. Col. Flood has received the en dorsement and active support of the bar associations o f Appomattox, Buckingham and Cumberland coun ties, and bas been urged to become a candidate for the judgeship by friends from all parts of the State. State Senator Charles T . Moses, who is actively supporting Col. Flood, stated this week that he had been highly gratified at the pledges from mëmberS of the General Assembly to support Col. Flood and that bis nomination for the vacancy on the first ballot was very probable, R . E . Garland, of Farmville, and J . Kent Early, attorneys of Farm villeand Charlotte Court House res pectively, have also been mentioned in connection with the vacancy.Mr. Garland is 40 years of age and has been a member of the Prince Edward bar for 16 years. Mr. Early is a former commonwealths attorney of Charlotte coun and unsuccessful ly opposed State Senator Moaes for the state senate in 1934. Col. Flood has outstanding qual- ftcations fitting him for the circuit bench. He is an alumnus of Wash ington and Lee University and the U, of Virginia, and took a law course at Oxford University, London. He bagan the practice of law in 1917, and was Commonwealths Attorney
